On Tue, 12 Jun 2001 ghouston@... wrote:

> FYI, there is a new project to extend JUnit so it can easily drive
> GUI tests.  Please contribute ideas to:
> http://sourceforge.net/projects/jfcunit


I just downloaded and looked at their code.  They have a fatal, from my
perspective, flaw.  Namely, to generate events against the components they
create a Java level event and post it to the event queue like so:

            queue.postEvent(new MouseEvent(ultimate,
                          MouseEvent.MOUSE_ENTERED,
                    new Date().getTime(), 0,
                    comp.getLocationOnScreen().x
                        -ultimate.getLocationOnScreen().x,
                    comp.getLocationOnScreen().y
                        -ultimate.getLocationOnScreen().y, 0, false));
	...etc...

The problem with this is that they do not exercise the native level code
in the slightest, so they are not getting complete code coverage.  Like I
said in my earlier email, my situation is different from y'all since my
job is to help validate the JDK and we need to validate as much as we can.

The difference between using Robot, and the above, is that Robot asks
the operating system to generate a system level event, that acts for all
intents and purposes like any event generated by a user twidling the mouse
or typing on the keyboard.  The event arrives in Java in the same way and
manner as any real event generated by a real user, and more importantly it
follows the same code paths those real events would follow.  This way
there are two advantages: 1) we can test AWT heavyweight components, 2) we
have complete coverage of the AWT native code, the AWT support code, and
the Swing classes.  Even for a pure Swing application, there is AWT code
that executes under the sheets (JFrame is, for instance, a wrapper around
Window).

- David Herron
